“Ah! You sceptical person!” laughed Svidrigaïlov. “I have no need of that money. It’s simply done from humanity. She wasn’t ‘a louse,’ you know.” 

He pointed to the corner. 

“Come, you’ll agree. Is Luzhin to go on living, or is she to die? If I didn’t help them, Polenka would go the same way.”

Raskolnikov turned white and cold. 

“How do you know?” he whispered, hardly able to breathe.

“I lodge here at Madame Resslich’s, the other side of the wall. I’m a neighbour.”

“Really?”

“Yes!” Svidrigaïlov shook with laughter. “You’ve interested me enormously. We shall become friends, you’ll see.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Svidrigaïlov reveals his knowledge of Raskolnikov's past actions and expresses a desire to help, highlighting the moral complexities of their situation.
